text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today 
i am showing you one of my absolute favorite

desserts but up until recently i always thought 
it was a very difficult thing to make and I think

because back when I was a kid we tried to make 
it at home and I remember it turning out just

completely disastrously so I think in my mind 
I've always thought that this is not something

you make at home and it's not something a lot of 
people make at home but I just recently tried it

again and it is totally doable and so I thought 
huh it's a lot easier than I thought so I'm going
to share it with you it is called bua loy nam king Bua loy means floating lotus and it's our

term for dumplings type dessert and Nam King is 
ginger tea so there are these black sesame filled

sticky chewy dumplings that is served in a sweet 
ginger tea it is so comforting and delicious and

it's something you can make in advance and you can 
pull out and put together whenever you're ready to

eat let's get started so I'm gonna start with 
the filling so I've got some black sesame seeds

here now you want these to be roasted all you have 
to do is just stir them around in a dry pan over

medium-low heat and you might wonder well how can 
you tell when these are roasted because they're

black right so what I do is I throw in some white 
sesame seeds just a little bit and then they watch

the color of the white sesame seeds so as soon as 
they turn golden then you pull the whole thing off

if you don't have white sesame seeds there are 
a couple of things you can watch for I will talk

about them in the written recipe on the website 
okay so now I'm going to grind these in my coffee

grinder now I tried using a food processor for 
this and it just doesn't get them quite as fine

you want this to be quite fine otherwise they 
won't stick together very well if you've got a

lot of coarseness in there so you could mortar 
and pestle it too but that takes a long time

and you don't want to overdo it because you don't 
want to turn this into tahini like eventually

it'll just liquify in its own oil but what you're 
looking for is for it to start to get moist like

if you notice at the bottom of your coffee grinder 
it's already starting to stick that's what you're

going for and that's it it takes literally like 
five seconds all right so the filling is super

easy I'm gonna start out with some coconut oil you 
can also do butter a lot of vendors in Thailand do

shortening which is not healthy for you so you 
shouldn't use it but either butter or coconut

oil and the fat is actually really important 
it's gonna allow the the filling to be solid

when you form it into balls but then when you eat 
it and it's warm it's like melty and soft so you

definitely want to use salt fat that is solid 
at room temperature okay some palm sugar you

can totally use white sugar for this but hey why 
not add a little extra flavor right a little bit

of salt the salt is so important do not forget it 
or it's not gonna taste as good and then I'm gonna

cook this just over low heat until the sugar is 
melted so now that your sugar is melted it's not

gonna mix with the oil that's totally fine I'm 
gonna add my sesame seeds and the sesame seeds

are going to absorb all that liquid I'm actually 
gonna turn off the heat now and there you go so

what you're looking for is for it to be like a 
paste that you can form into balls cuz eventually

that's what we're gonna do so it needs to stick 
together well but not too runny if it is too runny

just grind a little more sesame seeds and add 
to it to help absorb that fat now we're gonna

let that cool before we can do anything with it so 
while our filling is cooling let's make the ginger

tea so I've got some ginger here a lot because I 
like the spicy you can totally do less this will

be pretty spicy and I've just pounded it in my 
mortar and pestle to really get the juices release

and I'm just gonna dump it in my boiling water 
yeah without splashing yourself with hot water so

this will take about 20 minutes oh my god sesame 
seats in there somehow you didn't see that yes and

so this will just simmer for 20 minutes and it's 
as simple as that so while the tea is steeping

in the filling is chilling we're gonna make the 
dough which could not be simpler two ingredients

glutinous rice flour and water that's it but the 
choice of flour is so important you cannot get

this wrong glutinous rice flour comes in a green 
bag like this there's regular rice flour that

comes in a red bag and it will not work whatsoever 
you need this flour okay so with this you want

to add water and the amount of water is not super 
exact so there needs to be some judgment involved

so I always like to start with a little and it 
would be too little and then you keep adding and

little by little is important because this is the 
kind of dough where once you get close too big of

a splash and that's it it's gone too runny very 
quickly and the exact amount of water you need

will sort of depend on the humidity of the flour 
if it's old it'll be drier I might have just done

too much guys this is what I'm telling you one two 
a big of a splash so what I'm gonna do is just to

be safe I'm gonna pour out this extra water and 
hopefully I don't have to add any flour and if you

do get it too wet just add a little more flour 
but it's just you know now you've got too much

dough so what you're looking for is for the dough 
too it should not be sticking to the bottom of

the bowl anymore it shouldn't really stick too 
much to your hands either but at this point if

you feel like okay it's a little stiff I wanted at 
touch more water this is what you do you literally

like touched water with your hand and then you do 
this like it does not take a lot at all and then

you just keep doing that until you feel like okay 
this is really nice and soft and I think we're

good so the filling is cool enough we're gonna 
form the fillings into balls first and each ball

I recommend should be about 9 grams if you get 
eight fine you get ten fine but any bigger any

smaller than that will ruin your dough to filling 
ratio which is one of the key features of this of

this desert and so you just grab a little compress 
it into a ball it doesn't need to be completely

round at this point something like that you weigh 
it and see you how good you are oh my god that's 9

grams no it's not it's 10 close enough so I take 
a little bit off and then I put on this plate

and once you've got these little cute balls just 
put them in the freezer so that they will firm up

which will make it a lot easier for you to wrap 
off again so the teas done simmering your house

should smell so good right now and you can just 
drain it or I'm just gonna use my mesh skimmer

and fish everything out now I'm gonna sweeten 
this with dark brown sugar so dark brown sugar is

traditional for this and you can make it as sweet 
or as not sweet as you like alright so the balls

are nice and frozen or ginger tea is ready only 
one more thing left to do is to wrap the dumplings

so first what I'm gonna do is I'm going to oil my 
hands and this is just the coconut oil but it can

be whatever oil now the dough should probably also 
be weighed because I take back probably should be

weighed because the worst thing you want to have 
is a dumpling with dough that is too thick then

you know it's really doughy and it's too much 
dough and it's bland cuz the flavor is not in

the dough so for a nine gram ball I would do 12 
to 13 grams of dough 8 I'm not very good at this

at all there we go 12 so first I roll it into a 
ball and then I press it down until it's about

this big your because my biggest fear is touching 
these sesame balls and then touching the dough and

then you get black stuff all over the dough so I'm 
gonna pick up the sesame balls with tongs and then

my thumb press it down and then as you see I'm 
gonna sort of slowly coax the dough around the

ball once I get here I let go and I do not use 
this thumb which has black sesame on it to touch

this ever again you probably accidentally do that 
a couple times but to keep things nice and clean

this thumb touches nothing except the top of that 
ball and so you want to make sure it's all nice

and sealed and then it looks ridiculous now but 
you just roll it into a ball and there you have

it a nice and round dumpling so you can make these 
balls in advance by the way keeping the fridge or

even the freezer and then whenever you're ready 
you pick it up from here this is the beauty of

these things so that's why you can buy these 
things from the frozen section at the Asian

grocery store so you can apply the same concept 
all you have to do is boil these in water for

about five minutes if they've been sitting they 
might get a flat edge doesn't really matter but

if you care just give them another roll be gentle 
now because the filling will have softened by this

point at first they will sink eventually they 
will float a lot of people say once they float

they're done once they floated means the dough is 
cooked but I find they do need another one to two

minutes to make sure the inside is hot also have 
a bowl of room-temperature water ready it if you

have a couple of batches to fry not to fry to boil 
leave the first batch in water and then they won't

stick together super simple to put it together you 
want to take a couple balls and then pour your hot

ginger tea over oh yes oh they're so cute a cute 
bowl is a must-have so is a spoon shaped like this

and I call this a Thai spoon I don't know what's 
the word for it so now you might be wondering now

how do I eat this so I'm gonna tell you there is 
a way to eat it this is a to biter not a one biter

and be very careful the inside can be incredibly 
hot so make relatively certain that it is cooled

down enough that you won't burn your mouth okay so 
you basically just bite off half of the bowl and

this is what you got inside notes the thickness 
of that dough that is exactly what you want no

thicker cuz any more than this it'll be super 
doughy the filling is holding together enough

so it's not spewing all over the place some people 
like to make it so that if you bite into it it'll

just like the filling is so soft that it comes out 
I don't like that because then it contaminates my

soup my filling is all escape so this is just the 
perfect consistency make sure there's soup in your

spoon you eat the other half so comforting that 
ginger the heat from the ginger and the sweetness

and nuttiness from the sesame there is no better 
food pairing the dough is super soft so think

mochi that is the consistency that we've got soft 
and chewy and if you had this you know how good it

is if you're going to make this the recipe is 
on hot Thai Kitchen calm and please check out

that post before you make it I'm going to include 
a lot of little tips here and there that will help

make this process easier that I couldn't cover 
today so please don't make it before you read the

recipe okay and if you haven't subscribed to the 
show make sure you do so you never miss an awesome

recipe like this and if you want to join our 
patreon club check out all the information in the

description box below and I will see you next time 
for your next delicious time destiny in my teacher

oh you're kidding do you know yes you you always 
get sesame in your teeth after so it's authentic
